762727.name: Ocean Fidget Blanket
762727.notes_html:
This lap sized fidget blanket was designed to have several elements to play with, but still look beautiful. The chest opens with a button clasp and there is a string of pearls inside. The jellyfish has lots of flowing tentacles to fiddle with. The fish can wiggle around in the water on their short movement tracks. The clam opens and closes.

Materials:
4.25 mm hook
Worsted weight yarn in your preferred colours.
Beads
Stitch marker
Yarn needle
Button

771527.name: Ostomy bag and stoma for amigurumi toys
771527.notes_html:
A set of amigurumi ostomy bag and stoma that you can place on a crochet/knit stuffed animal or doll. The bag is removable and 3D. Ideal for giving away to young children with a stoma, wether ileostomy, colostomy or urostomy.

Really easy and quick to make. Very short length of yarn needed.

This pattern is free for personal use and for giving away finished products. Please don’t redistribute this pattern without linking to the source.

The pattern is only for the stoma and bag, not for the entire toy.

Hippo design is by Zara Home and pig design is by Sharon Ojala (www.amigurumitogo.com).

776545.name: Nestelmuffs
776545.notes_html:
Die Idee zu den Nestelmuffs kommt vom LoveKnitting-Blog, dort heissen sie Twiddle-Muffs.Die Idee dabei ist, dass die Finger und der Tastsinn von den aufgenähten Details angesprochen werden, und dass die Hände warmgehalten werden.
Bei LoveKnitting findet ihr auch eine prima Anleitung für die Addi Rundstrickmaschine,googlet mal nach „loveknitting twiddlemuffs“.
Ich fand die Dinger so toll, ich hab mich gleich mal an die Strickmaschine gesetzt und einige Nestelmuffs nach eigenem Entwurf gestrickt. Das geht auf dem Grobstricker (Singer Solo) ratzfatz, man kann sie aber auch per Hand stricken, ich gebe für beides eine Anleitung. Ich habe einen Rollrand gestrickt, das geht fix und ist schön weich und elastisch. Man kann zum Aufnähen alles Mögliche verwenden, ich habe hier mal meine gesammelten Häkelrosen genommen, von denen hatte ich noch reichlich. Man kann aber auch Perlen, Glöckchen, Glitzersteine und allen möglichen Kleinkram draufnähen, Hauptsache es sieht hübsch aus und die Finger haben was zum Spielen.

Man braucht etwa 50 g Wolle für einen Muff, ich habe Sockenwolle 4fädig doppelt genommen.

users.about_me:
**Stricken ist mein Lebenselixier!** :)
Ich bin von Beruf Fachinformatikerin und wurde nach einer langen, abwechslungsreichen Karriere in der IT Branche vor einigen Jahren aus gesundheitlichen Gründen in Frührente geschickt.
Der Abschied aus dem Berufsleben ist mir nicht leicht gefallen, aber ich habe die viele freie Zeit genutzt, um meinen vielen Hobbies nachzugehen. Ich male (hauptsächlich bairische Landschaften in Aquarell), ich schreibe Kinderbücher, ich pflege meine Homepage mit dem beliebten [Inselfisch-Kochbuch][1], ich bastle mit Papier und Perlen und filze und nähe und… die Liste ist lang, ich bin ein sehr kreativer Mensch und habe viele unterschiedliche Interessen. Aber vor allen Dingen Stricke und Häkle ich “was das Zeug hält”.
Meine liebste Technik ist das Patchworkstricken oder modulare Stricken nach Horst Schulz. 

**Knitting is my elixir!** :)
I am a professional computer scientist and have been sent into an early retirement because of health reasons some years ago. It wasn't easy for me to say goodbye to my professional carreer, but I have used the free time on my hands for my many hobbies. I paint (mainly Bavarian landscape watercolors), I write childrens books, I host my own homepage including a very popular online cookbook (the [Inselfisch-Kochbuch][2]), I do creative work with paper and pearls, I felt and I sew and... my list of interests is long, I am a very creative person and have many different interests. But mainly I knit and crochet "hell for keather" :)
My favorite technique is patchwork or modular knitting after Horst Schulz. 
  [1]: https://evileu.de/inselfisch-kochbuch/
  [2]: https://evileu.de/inselfisch-kochbuch/

780945.name: NICU Adorable Octopi
780945.notes_html:
I worked as a nurse until injury & illness took me away from my passion. I love helping ppl so when I was asked if I could make an octopus for a baby in the NICU I was happy to help!

780973.name: Al's Fidget Toy
780973.notes_html:
Here is a quick and easy pattern to make a fidget toy, with pleasing texture and comforting weight and solidity that can be attached to a key chain, or back-pack, or belt loop, etc. I’ve also included instructions for how to make this into a bracelet.

Fidget toys have been found to be helpful for people with anxiety issues, restless energy (such as people with ADD, ADHD etc), and even some stages of Alzheimer’s disease, as it gives them something to direct the restless energy into. This nearly unconscious redirection can be soothing and calming, and enhance the ability to focus on tasks.

I’ve named this pattern for my Father-in-law, who suffers from Alzheimer’s. Seeing the constant restless energy in the motion of his hands inspired me to come up with a fidget toy that would be simple, comforting, and easily carried/kept handy.

You will need a small amount of sock weight yarn (less than 50 yards) to make either the toy or the bracelet. For each item you make, you will also want a standard sized play marble. One of my testers came up with the idea of making the key-chain longer, and adding a second marble, which is another good possibility.

users.about_me:
I'm an introvert, and  I'm a romantic. But Jane Austen also has her incisive wit, and LM Montgomery is more than kindred spirits. If I don't have a project on my hooks, and a documentary or podcast playing, then I'm likely to have a good book in my hands.  I've also been known to dabble in beading (stitch markers, jewelry) and paper crafting when the mood strikes.
  

 
Wish Lists / inspiration for Swaps  (please don't feel obligated to use the stores the links are from (except ravelry stores)...If you can find items from the lists elsewhere, feel free (especially the a-z store) ;) ). Also I am a happy friend of re-using, thrifting / etc.

[Ravelry][1]
[Amazon][2]
[Thriftbooks][3] Better World Books or alibris, etc., are also excellent.
[Etsy][4]

Quotes 'n' Bits

"He will feed his flock like a shepherd.
    He will carry the lambs in his arms,
holding them close to his heart.
    He will gently lead the mother sheep with their young." -Isaiah 40:11 NLT

"Now at last they were beginning Chapter One of the Great Story no one on earth has ever read, which goes on forever: in which every chapter is better than the one before."                   --CS Lewis, The Last Battle

"I am a princess. All girls are. Even if they live in tiny old attics. Even if they dress in rags, even if they aren't pretty, or smart, or young. They're still princesses. All of us."                 --Frances Hodges Burnett, A Little Princess

"In 900 years of time and space, I've never met anyone who wasn't important"                                     --the Doctor

"The Lord your God is with you, 
       He is mighty to save. 
     He will take great delight in you,
      He will quiet you with His love,
     He will rejoice over you with singing."            -Zephaniah 3:17

"Death cannot stop true love. All it can do is delay it for a while."  
                                                                             --The Princess Bride

“...an infinite Power must be infinitely little as well as infinitely great. We are neither, therefore there are things too little as well as too great for us to apprehend.”                                               --LM Montgomery

  [3]: https://www.thriftbooks.com/list/share/738bbfdf1a779a6f/
  [4]: https://www.etsy.com/people/robindykema/favorites/wish-list?ref=cl_share_button

787806.name: Amazababy Twiddle Blankie
787806.sizes_available: Approximately 36 cm x 33 cm (14" x 13") size of sample in DK - instructions for larger sizes included
787806.gauge_description: 19 stitches and 24 rows = 4 inches in stockinette stitch
787806.notes_html:
This is a pattern for hand knitters.
I have also written a similar pattern for machine knitters, Amazababy 3D Baby Blanket.

Amaze a special baby in your life!

This eye-catching blankie is for anyone who likes fiddling, twiddling, twisting and tweaking, but was designed particularly with curious babies in mind. Knitted in a suitably firm cotton or cotton-rich yarn, it has 3D hills with tweakable tips, a rolled edge that can be unrolled and returns to its starting position, and tags like a pair of rabbit’s ears at each corner.

The piece is started with waste yarn/a provisional cast on, and the trims are knitted on afterwards. Only one colour is used at a time.

The sample was knitted using Debbie Bliss Cotton DK, which is a thick DK, but any firm, cotton-rich yarn can be used. Instructions are included for making larger pieces using more stitches and rows. Whichever yarn is used, the needles will need to be smaller than usual for the yarn.

YARN USED FOR PICTURED SAMPLE:
Debbie Bliss Cotton DK, 168 metres (184 yards) each of 3 colours allowing for swatching
50 metres (54 yards) of similar yarn for waste yarn

OTHER TOOLS:
3.75 mm (US 5), straight or circular needles, minimum 30 cm (12”) long (or size to get a tight gauge in stocking stitch in your yarn)
tapestry needle
5 stitch markers, if wanted

Difficulty: intermediate

This pattern includes both written and charted instructions for the main part of the pattern.

Directions for making and attaching the trim
are given in written form with the aid of a photo-tutorial.

There are 4 separate files for download - choose those you need:

File 1. Cover

File 2. Main part of pattern

File 2a. Page 5 only of main pattern (written instructions for main piece) adapted to make sense if printed in black and white

File 3. Appendix with photo-tutorials on working the stitch, attaching the trims, and working other sizes.

As of December 2019, I am seriously in love with 
\*TUNISIAN CROCHET \*\(TC\)

Tunisian crochet links:
https://tunicrochetweaver.wordpress.com/stitchpattern-gallery/

\*HAND KNITTING\*
All done on knitpro circulars, which I love.

HK links
[Dee’s No-Twist Circular Knitting Cast On **discussion**] (http://www.ravelry.com/discuss/techniques/2561516/1-25)

[Dee’s No-Twist Circular Knitting Cast On **video**](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FAoB9Rppsx8)
[Invisible join in the round](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=idghalAiuZQ)

[Intarsia in the round](https://www.google.com/search?q=%22intarsia+in+the+round%22&rlz=1C1ONGR_en-GBGB930GB930&oq=%22intarsia+in+the+round%22&aqs=chrome..69i57j0i512l5j0i22i30l4.6710j0j15&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8#kpvalbx=_WkpAYdjjA4eXsAfEy664Dw44)

[ladderback jacquard](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iLtuGY_M-ds)


\*MACHINE KNITTING\*
I have been a machine knitter since 1991.

In 2018 I started arranging **weekend get-togethers for machine knitters of all levels**. The plan is to meet every four months in a village hall in Worcestershire, where we share skills, knit and socialise. The last one was October 2021, the next one...? It's been a very odd couple of years hasn't it!

There are usually between 10 and 20 of us of at all levels of experience, with and without machines. We have a sale and swap table for yarns, patterns - anything even vaguely connected with machine knitting actually - and knitting machines have been bought and sold here too. 
There's plenty of local accommodation - including in pubs less that 5 minutes away by foot. Please get in touch if you're interested. 

\*My knitting machines\* some are **for sale**

SINGER/SUPERBA
Metal bed: System 9000 plus 624 selection box, 2310 x2
Hobby: Big Phil (9mm), Singer 100 Compact (5mm) - something's wrong with it.
MOTOR, untested - if you are interested and can pick this up, get in touch.

SILVER/KNITMASTER
Electronic: 560 and DesignaKnit 8. 
Punchcard: Knitmaster MK70, HK 160 (Both 6 mm, 18 stitch rpt) 
326x2 – 4.5 mm, 24 stitch rpt, built in knitradar 
155 - chunky 12 stitch repeat machine
LK 150 6.5 mm plastic machine. Mine's labelled "Option 4", but it's the same machine.

BROTHER/JONES
800 - 4.5mm, 12 stitch early punchcard mechanism, great for lace - **for sale** 

710 – 4.5mm push button patterning, plus pattern can be slid across the bed. 881 (standard gauge, 24-stitch rpt pc, built in knitleader, lace carriage. Garter carriage (GC 88II) to play on it with. 

OTHER
Record - 5mm. I haven’t got the hang of it yet. Anyone want it?










General links


[playing with colour combinations](http://paletton.com/#uid=1000u0kllllaFw0g0qFqFg0w0aF)


Strike-through code for text: < del > then the text < /del >
(but **no spaces at all**)

~what happens?~

----------------------------------------
TC notes

RIB-LIKE STITCH COMBINATIONS

Saloniki stitch
Foundation row as normal, then 1 row repeat
FP: [TSS, TFS, TFS] repeat   (This increases loops by 50% - dealt with in RP)
RP: ch1, treat all TFS pairs as 1 stitch, reducing stitches back to original count

816832.name: Fidget Muff
816832.notes_html:
Dementia patients are often frustrated with extra energy and a case of ‘the fidgets’ that can be alleviated by giving them something to do with their hands. I designed this muff with very soft yarn (such as Caron Simply Soft) to give a cozy place for warming cold fingers. By adding different textures through a variety of stitches and embellishments such as buttons, tassels, beads, and pompoms, idle fingers can find a variety of sensations. There are even hidden beads on the inside for added entertainment when just using it as a hand-warmer.

Add your own touches with specific colors, pompoms, or anything else that seems fun and appropriate!

Skill level: Intermediate to advanced. There are a variety of stitches involved and places where it’s acceptable to vary from the pattern if necessary.

I designed this muff with very soft yarn (such as Caron Simply Soft) to give a cozy place for warming cold fingers. By adding different textures through a variety of stitches and embellishments such as buttons, tassels, beads, and pompoms, idle fingers can find a variety of sensations. There are even hidden beads on the inside for added entertainment when just using it as a hand-warmer. 

Add your own touches with specific colors, pompoms, or anything else that seems fun and appropriate!

Skill level: Intermediate to advanced. There are a variety of stitches involved and places where it's acceptable to vary from the pattern if necessary.

835113.name: Fidget and Fiddle Muff
835113.notes_html:
Level: Easy

Make a crocheted soft pastel sensory twiddle and fiddle fidget muff! This is a fully lined tube with incredibly soft washable acrylic yarn to comfort and nestle hands and wrists. Soft and textural embellishments to allow sensory stimulation, bring focus, encourage calming and decrease anxiety.

Finished size: approximately 11” long and 11” around.

Not a crocheter? I also have these ready-made in my Etsy shop!

users.about_me:
Over my lifetime, I've practiced almost every fabric and yarn skill out there including sewing, embroidery, cross stitch, macrame, knitting and more. A few years ago, I taught myself to crochet. Little did I know it would become such a big part of my life! It quickly became my favorite art/craft form, and since then, few days pass without a crochet hook in my hand. One of my most enjoyable things to do is sit on my front porch with a cup of coffee in my hand and my current crochet project in a basket at my feet. 

I find the motions of hooking crochet stitches calming, peaceful and zen like. It's easy to crochet almost anywhere, so my crochet bag comes along on my travels. I also teach elementary school students how to crochet and have seen how this intentional practice helps calm and focus anxious and overactive students.

Crochet stitches can be combined to create almost anything, and allows the crocheter immense artistic flexibility. Did you know crochet is the only fiber art form that can't be created by machine? 

I have made enough crochet items to fill my closets (and those of friends and family) and my yarn stash has taken over my home in British Columbia, Canada. I still create many items to gift to others and donate to worthy causes, and my little Etsy and Ravelry shoppes allow me to send my crochet projects and patterns around the world.

I sometimes use paid or free crochet patterns, but I now often create my own patterns as well. I get such joy from sharing my favorite patterns and projects around the world. I offer all my patterns as custom orders in my Etsy shoppe, so if you would rather have any of my patterns crocheted for you, I can do that too.  

Thank you for taking a look at my little Ravelry shop. Please favorite my shop and love my patterns, or check out CranbrookCrochet on Etsy, Facebook (CranbrookCrochet) or Instagram (ShariReid65, CranbrookCrochet) to stay in the loop as new patterns are added.

835727.name: Twiddlemuff
835727.notes_html:
Twiddlemuffs are easy-to-make hand muffs that are comforting and therapeutic for Alzheimer’s, arthritis and dementia patients. They use bright and colourful embellishments to encourage movement and brain stimulation. Adding things like buttons and ribbons attracts attention and creates something to twiddle with!

A great pattern to use up odds and ends of many colours and textures of yarn! This pattern can easily be adapted and customised to fit your experience level and materials.

Find on page 14 of this PDF: http://ukhandknitting.com/contentfiles/patterns/ukhandKni...

854678.name: Fidget Blanket
854678.notes_html:
This blanket was designed with Alzheimer’s patients, and other persons suffering from any cognitive disability, in mind.
It uses a lot of notions, and though oyu might think it is cost intensive, it is not. Most of the notions are things you probably have around your home that you no longer use.
Plus this blanket is easy to customise with the supplies you already have- you only need to let your imagination free rein
It is made in 6 blocks which are then seamed together.
All blocks have some form of notion or the other, so there will be a lot of sewing.
You will need less than 500 yards of yarn to make all 6 blocks.

872021.name: Sensory Montessori quiet cube
872021.sizes_available: 12 cm/ 5” in side and 24 cm/10” in height
872021.notes_html:
This cube is a tactile and musical sensory toy of Montessori inspiration.

Montessori is an educative method developed by Maria Montessori, this method is based on the freedom to choose the educational path and on the respect for the natural development of the child. Children must be left free to explore the world. It‘s in this context that sensory materials take shape, they aren’t just games but tools to help the child in the initial period of his life in which he has a particular need to perform sensory activities.
With Montessori materials children develop their cognitive powers through direct experience: seeing, hearing, tasting, smelling, touching, and movement. I designed this cube so that it could reflect the characteristics of Montessori materials: natural and quality materials, simple and realistic shapes, each cube face dedicated to a single activity linked to a precise sensation to give to the child. A simple and safe toy with which the child can interact freely and that will grow with him.

The cube consists of 6 faces crocheted separately and then joined wit a round of simple crochet stitches.

I made this cube for my 8 month old niece, since she is attracted by any sounds and she likes rattles then I inserted a rattle box inside the sun and the cloud but you can quietly not put them, it’s your free choice

This cube is of 12 cm/ 5” in side and 24 cm/10 “ in height. The dimensions are approximate and may vary depending on the yarn and the number of crochet used.

Not: this pattern corresponds to 9 patterns in one:

  1. Basic square of each faces of the cube
  2. Handle face
  3. Rabbit face
  4. Sun face
  5. Apple face
  6. Flowers face
  7. Tree face
  8. Carrot
  9. Cloud

With these pattern you can do not only this sensorial cube but a lot of other things: you can use the basic square or any other cube face to make a simple potholder or a baby blanket and so on.

Materials:

  • Schachenmayr cotton yarn ( 50g~125m / 1.75oz~137yds ) in colors indicated in the pattern;
  • crochet hook nº2.5 mm
  • polyester fiberfill
  • needle
  • pins
  • scissors
  • stitch marker
  • Optional: 12x27 mm rattle box insert

GAUGE: not essential.

The pattern is suitable for an intermediate level of crochet knowledge. You should know basic crochet stitches including chain, slip stitch, single crochet, half double crochet, double crochet, decrease or sc2tog and how to start with a magic ring.

users.about_me:
Hi, I’m Elisa, a crochet designer. 

Since I was a child I have always observed my mother crocheting and I never imagined that I would do the same, in fact I started by chance to relieve the stress of the last exam at the university and always by chance I approached the world of crochet design.  Drawing patterns allows me to give free rein to my creative vein and also to the mathematical one, because crochet is math.

In my patterns I try to give simple solutions for everyone so that crochet can always be a relaxing moment in which to break away from the stress of everyday life and create something beautiful, practical and safe for the people we care about.

I decided to share all my patterns for free, you can find them on my blog

901286.name: Twiddlemuff
901286.notes_html:
This is a basic pattern / tutorial for making a crochet twiddlemuff, which is a sensory accessory for people with dementia and Alzheimers. It provides tactile stimulation for restless hands, and warmth for cold fingers.

As there are no set rules/ patterns for making a twiddlemuff, this pattern is more of a guideline, although I have given specific pattern instructions for the ones pictured.

You can use up lots of scrap yarn, a huge range of embellishments - just have fun and let your creativity run riot!

908676.gauge_pattern: Stockinette Stitch knit in the round
908676.name: Worry Bear
908676.gauge_description: 24 stitches and 32 rows = 4 inches in Stockinette Stitch knit in the round
908676.notes_html:
Feeling worried, anxious or need something to hold? Worry Bear is designed to fit in your hand or pocket. Soft, squishable, and easily hidden, Worry Bear can help you share your worries, so you feel calmer. This is an ideal fidget tool for anyone with anxiety or neuro-diverse challenges like ADHD, Sensory Processing Disorder, Autism Spectrum or Alzheimer’s disease. Make a Worry Bear for someone you love or to offer your nearest hospital, school, or beyond.

This is perfect for using up odds and ends.

This is ideal for an advanced beginner or intermediate knitter; to knit Worry Bear, you’ll need to knit in the round, purl, increase, decrease, slip stitches, and do a three–needle bind–off.

Accessibility Note: This pattern offers an additional Low Vision pdf option, with Arial 24 point sans serif font in all black text and photo captions. It has no italics. All of the directions are fully written out. If there’s a chart included, there are also written instructions- the chart is not needed to complete the pattern.

Notes:
• Row gauge is not important for this pattern; nearly all measurements are given in inches/cm as well as in rows.
• Gauge is not as important here as creating a firm fabric that will stand up to being stuffed and handled a lot. Select a needle size that is at least 2 or 3 sizes lower than called for on the yarn ball band when in doubt.
• A Note on Yarn:
When choosing yarn, remember that Worry Bears often get dirty or end up in pockets and may take trips through the washing machine and dryer. It’s good to use machine washable materials so your bear doesn’t felt or shrink by accident.

Materials:
Yarn Amount:
–For both sizes of bear:
Approximately 55 yards/50 meters of machine washable sport weight or DK yarn that knits to gauge. If you knit a bigger bear than described here, you’ll need more yarn.
Other materials:
–Small amount of washable stuffing. For eco–friendly stuffing, consider using cotton rags, superwash or down breed wool roving (a down breed is usually resistant to felting)
–A ribbon, contrasting yarn or tape to tie around the bear’s neck (optional)
– Embroidery floss, thread or lace weight yarn to create a face (optional)

Sample Used:
For Smaller Bear:
1 skein Rowan Pure Wool DK, 100% superwash merino wool, 142 yards (130m)/50g per skein, Cloud, # 058

For Larger Bear:
1 skein Rowan Pure Wool DK, 100% superwash merino wool, 142 yards (130m)/50g per skein, Indigo, # 010

Note: Rowan Pure Wool DK is discontinued, but has been replaced by Rowan Pure Wool Superwash DK, which knits to the same gauge and has the same fiber content.

Note: These pattern samples were worked entirely with dpns. You can choose to use magic loop or another technique if so desired.

Notions Required:
Stitch marker
Tape measure or ruler
Tapestry needle

941633.name: Fidget Mitt
941633.notes_html:
(Français suivra)

What? The basic Fidget Mitt crochet pattern.

Why? I was once asked to custom-make a pair of these for a client who had a daughter with ADHD. I tought it was a great idea so now we make a few for our craft fairs. I designed these fidget mitts primarily for children, so instructions are for small sizes and teenagers. While they can be made in any yarn, I believe pima cotton, the same kind we use for knitted knockers are best for its’ softness on children’s skin.

Who might enjoy it? People who want to try something non-invasive for attention deficit issues to keep focus.

What you need: About 136 yards of pima cotton (like Knitpicks comfy sport), a 3.5 mm hook and some items to fasten to the outside of the mitt (keep in mind any security concerns for these added items).

Feedback is always welcome & I hope to see your projects!
Email: nadine@mereetfilletricots.ca
© MereEtFilleTricots 2019
See: http://www.mereetfilletricots.ca

Qu’est-ce que c’est? Les gants sans doigts de base ‘Fidget Mitt’.

Pourquoi? Une fois, on m’a demandé de faire une paire de ceux-ci par une cliente qui avait une fille avec un TDAH. Je pensais que c’était une bonne idée, nous en fabriquons quelques-uns pour nos foires artisanales. J’ai conçu ces gants Fidget principalement pour les enfants. Les instructions sont donc pour les petites tailles. Bien qu’ils puissent être confectionnés avec n’importe quel fil, je crois que le coton pima, le même que celui que nous utilisons pour les nichons tricotés, est idéal pour sa douceur sur la peau des enfants.

Qui aimerait? Les gens qui veulent essayer une méthode non-invasive pour aider les déficits d’attention des enfants.

Vous aurez besoin: À peu près 124 m de coton pima (du type Knitpicks Comfy Sport) et un crochet 3.5 mm, ainsi que des items à joindre au gants (garder en tête toute considération de sécurité concernant ces items et les enfants).

J’apprécie tous vos commentaires & j’espère bien voir vos produits finis! Courriel : nadine@mereetfilletricots.ca
© MereEtFilleTricots 2019
See: http://www.mereetfilletricots.ca
941633.notes:
(Français suivra)

**What?** The basic Fidget Mitt crochet pattern.

**Why?** I was once asked to custom-make a pair of these for a client who had a daughter with ADHD. I tought it was a great idea so now we make a few for our craft fairs. I designed these fidget mitts  primarily for children, so instructions are for small sizes and teenagers. While they can be made in any yarn, I believe pima cotton, the same kind we use for knitted knockers are best for its’ softness on children’s skin.

**Who might enjoy it?** People who want to try something non-invasive for attention deficit issues to keep focus.

**What you need**: About 136 yards of pima cotton (like Knitpicks comfy sport), a 3.5 mm hook and some items to fasten to the outside of the mitt (keep in mind any security concerns for these added items).

Feedback is always welcome & I hope to see your projects! 
Email: nadine@mereetfilletricots.ca
© MereEtFilleTricots 2019
See: http://www.mereetfilletricots.ca

945711.name: Basic Twiddle Muff
945711.yarn_weight_description: Any gauge - designed for any gauge
945711.notes_html:
(Français suivra)

This is a basic Twiddle Muff crochet pattern offered for free!

It can be adapted and changed depending on yarn, hook size or personalized the way you wish.

The Twiddle Muff was first introduced in Great Britain and has shown to be beneficial for Alzheimer’s and dementia patients by calming anxiety, keeping their fidgety hands busy and warm if needed.

Please keep in mind any safety concerns about the fidget items you wish to add to the muff.

Feedback is always welcome & I hope to see your projects!
Email: nadine@mereetfilletricots.ca
© MereEtFilleTricots 2019
See: http://www.mereetfilletricots.ca

Ceci est un patron de base de Twiddle Muff au crochet offert gratuitement!

Il peut être adapté et modifié en fonction du fil, de la taille du crochet ou personnalisé comme vous le souhaitez.

Le ‘Twiddle Muff’ a été introduit pour la première fois en Grande-Bretagne et s’est avéré bénéfique pour les patients atteints de la maladie d’Alzheimer et de démence en calmant l’anxiété, tout en gardant leurs mains occupées et au chaud si nécessaire.

Veuillez garder à l’esprit toutes les préoccupations de sécurité relatives aux articles que vous souhaitez ajouter au manchon.

J’apprécie tous vos commentaires & j’espère bien voir vos produits finis! Courriel : nadine@mereetfilletricots.ca
© MereEtFilleTricots 2019
See: http://www.mereetfilletricots.ca

952717.name: Emil: the Preemie Octopus
952717.gauge_description: 34 stitches and 40 rows = 4 inches in sc
952717.notes_html:
Meet Emil, the cute preemie octopus crochet pattern. If you’re looking for a fun Crochet for Charity pattern, Emil is scientifically proven to soothe premature babies in the hospital.

According to Randi Palm, U.S. Project Ambassador for Octopus for a Preemie, “The purpose of the crocheted octopuses is to promote comfort and development for the pre-term babies while in the hospital. The tentacles of the soft octos mimic the feel of the umbilical cord in their tiny hands and have been found to soothe the babies and help prevent them from pulling on wires and tubes.”

Only single crochet stitches are used throughout the pattern, making it an easy project for beginners. Guidelines on size and construction are given to ensure you can donate your completed octopus to charity. Use up your scrap yarn while giving back with this printable PDF pattern.

PATTERN DETAILS
• Follows recommended size and construction for donation
• Beginner-friendly
• Only single crochets, increases and decreases.
• US crochet notations
• Illustrated step-by-step photos

MATERIALS
• 2.5 mm / US B1 crochet hook
• Fingering weight cotton yarn: For one octopus you need about 56 m / 61 yd of yarn.
• Tapestry needle

All my patterns are in English, using standard knitting and crochet terms but with tons of step by step pictures and more detailed explanations to make sure they are extra easy to follow even if you’re not a knit/crochet expert.

pattern_author.name: Knitting with Chopsticks
pattern_author.notes:
Hi there,

I’m Hortense, a passionate knitter, crocheter and yarn addict. I created Knitting with Chopsticks to share my creations and help you make your own.

It’s thanks to blogs like this one that I have learned most of what I know about knitting and crochet. My mom taught me the basics of knitting when I was a small girl, bored on the beach (yep, that’s possible when you are 10) and since then I haven’t stopped. Always looking to learn, do more, do better and share my love of yarn, I created Knitting with Chopsticks to make knitting and crochet as simple as it gets so YOU can create what YOU want the way YOU want it.

Engineer by trade, crafter by passion, you will usually find me playing with some yarn while watching the latest episode of Grey’s Anatomy (and probably eating some chocolate, I’m from Belgium, what can I say?).

Any questions, comments, are you just want to say hi, I’m happy to hear from you and will do my best to get back to you asap!

PS: Oh and if you want, I have some very convenient printable yarn jargon cheatsheets you can grab for FREE by joining my email list here: https://pages.knittingwithchopsticks.com/cheatsheets

users.about_me:
Hi, my name is Rose. If there is one thing I have not stopped doing since I picked up a crochet hook, it is crocheting, it brings me so much fulfilment. 
I started out my blog as LoopinglyMade, then changed it to Craft-Her and now I publish under Yarn Craftee. They are all me. So, if you see any of those names on patterns, they are from me. 
These names are under one umbrella Rose Obom. 

I am an eclectic designer, gaining inspiration from various sources. My patterns are often easy, and every now and then I like to design something challenging.

My goal is to crochet as much as I can for as long as I can, to design simple but classic designs that encourage people to create as well.
